awd_titl_txt: Dimensions: Eco-Evolutionary Drivers of Diversity in Toxic Algal Blooms
awd_abstract_narration:
Ecology and evolution are two significant biological processes that are often studied independently. Yet, it is likely that interactions between ecology and evolution are key to generating biological diversity. This project will study toxic algal blooms to understand how links between ecological and evolutionary processes shape biodiversity. The last decade has seen amazing advances in genome sequencing technology and biological data analysis. There is now an opportunity to apply this new technology to the study of algae. Algae are important for several reasons. Algae are the primary producers in most ocean and freshwater environments. Algae produce numerous substances including antibiotics and other potential human drugs. Algae also produce toxins that endanger human health and water quality. These toxic algal blooms are increasing in both frequency and severity across the globe. The resources developed as a result of this project will help better predict toxic algal blooms. This project will train undergraduate students in genomics and phylogenetic approaches. Outreach materials focused on the algae in aquarium habitats will also be developed for the Biosphere 2 facility in Arizona.

The goal of this research is to study a type of toxic alga called Prymnesium. Prymnesium is abundant in aquatic communities in Texas. The project will focus on study sites in Texas. The project will test the hypothesis that changes in toxicity shape the genetic diversity of Prymnesium populations. To do so, the project will first characterize the diversity of toxic algal blooms through whole genome sequencing of over 100 diverse Prymnesium strains. This will be the largest survey of genomic variation within a natural algal population to date. Second, the project will identify the molecular mechanisms of toxicity using RNA sequencing and network analysis. This approach will overcome the challenge of rapid, accurate identification of genes underlying functional traits. Third, the researchers will integrate the empirical data into mathematical models of eco-evolutionary feedbacks to predict all three dimensions (genetic, phylogenetic, and function) of biodiversity within toxic algal blooms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Toxic algal blooms are growing global concerns. These ecosystem disruptive events show striking parallels to invasive plant species on land, including production of toxins by the invading species and catastrophic loss of native biodiversity. Yet, efforts to understand the genetic and functional diversity of toxic bloom-forming species have been limited, limiting their utility as promising natural systems for studying invasive species. The toxic alga Prymnesium parvum, also known as the golden alga, is a significant threat to freshwater and brackish water ecosystems and is considered an invasive species in several North American freshwater reservoirs. Our work on this project has shown that the amount of genetic diversity present in golden algae is unprecedented. Evolutionary and biochemical analyses had previously identified three major groups of golden algae, with each clade producing unique toxins classified as A-, B-, or C-types. Our comparative analysis of genome variation revealed that the three groups of golden algae have dramatically different genome sizes. All three clades contained strains of different ploidy levels, including polyploids (3+ genome copies). In our pan genome analysis, 35% of gene families were conserved in all strains in the analysis while 65% were variable. Despite golden algae being eukaryotes, this high level of variation is far more characteristic of a bacterial species. Strikingly, the variable portion of the golden algae genome is enriched in gene families involved in biosynthesis of specialized metabolites including polyketides, which are thought to be the dominant toxin type produced by golden algae. This suggests that between strain toxin variation is high, and that the extreme diversity observed at the genomic level will have considerable phenotypic and ecological effects. Taken together, the extensive genomic differences observed indicates that the golden alga is not one species but several. Our surveys of golden algal blooms in Texas revealed that multiple cryptic species of golden algae can co-occur blooms, a fact that can now be accounted for to improve our understanding of golden algae blooms. 

This project resulted in the isolation of 48 new strains of golden algae recovered from seven different golden algal blooms in US reservoirs. These strains differ markedly in terms of feeding behavior, total DNA content, and biochemistry and are being used to studying how different cryptic species of golden algae respond to environmental change. This project has also generated genome level data for 84 unique strains of golden algae from across the world and generated the first chromosome-scale assembly for golden algae. This genome was recently used to discover genes involved in making golden algae toxic. The toxin biosynthesis genes discovered are a whopping 137,000 DNA base pairs long, which makes them the largest protein-coding genes yet characterized and push the bounds of what we thought genes could even look like. The discovery of these novel toxin biosynthesis genes opens new avenues of research into algal natural products. 

The broader impacts of the project included student training, data sharing, publications, and presentations. This project involved 4 postdoctoral trainees, 7 graduate students, 1 NSF postbaccalaureate researcher (who decided to continue their academic trajectory by pursuing a PhD), and 15 of undergraduates including one NSF Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) student. The project released multiple pieces of open access software as well as several molecular biology protocols for working with challenging algal DNA and RNA.
